content: The Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Act of 2016 establishes a Trust Fund and addresses various issues such as discrimination, civil rights violations, and public participation in regionalization. It also provides technical assistance to rural and small municipalities, improves residential onsite sewage disposal systems, and supports state water pollution control revolving funds and drinking water grant programs. The Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Act of 2016 establishes a Trust Fund under SEC. 9512 in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to address issues like discrimination, civil rights violations, and public participation in regionalization. The Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Act of 2016 establishes a Trust Fund in the Treasury of the United States called the 'Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Trust Fund'. The Trust Fund receives appropriations from the Secretary based on the increase in Federal revenues from section 952(e), with a yearly limit of $34,850,000,000. The funds in the Trust Fund can be used for purposes outlined in the Act without the need for further appropriation or fiscal year limitation. Section 952 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to define 'subpart F income' for controlled foreign corporations. The Administrator of the EPA allocates funds for a fiscal year. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency allocates funds from the Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Trust Fund for clean water programs and safe drinking water funding. The Administrator allocates funds from the Water Affordability, Transparency, Equity, and Reliability Trust Fund for clean water programs and safe drinking water funding. Of the allocated amount, 0.5% is for technical assistance, 44.5% for capitalization grants, and 3% for grants under specific sections of the Safe Drinking Water Act. SEC. 3. REPORT ON AFFORDABILITY, DISCRIMINATION, CIVIL RIGHTS VIOLATIONS, PUBLIC PARTICIPATION IN REGIONALIZATION, AND DATA COLLECTION. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will conduct a study on water and sewer services, focusing on water affordability, rates, funding effectiveness, discrimination, and civil rights violations in collaboration with the Civil Rights Division of the United States Department of Justice. The Administrator, in collaboration with the Civil Rights Division of the United States Department of Justice, will study discriminatory practices and civil rights violations by water and sewer service providers receiving Federal assistance. The study will also evaluate public participation in regionalizing public water systems and sewer services. The Administrator, in collaboration with the Civil Rights Division of the United States Department of Justice, will study discriminatory practices and civil rights violations by water and sewer service providers receiving Federal assistance. The study will also evaluate public participation in regionalizing public water systems and sewer services. The Administrator shall collect information on people living without water or sewer services, water service disconnections due to unpaid charges, and disparate effects based on race, gender, or socioeconomic status. A report is due within 1 year of the enactment of this Act. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of the enactment of this Act. The report will include the results of a study on discriminatory practices and civil rights violations by water and sewer service providers, along with recommendations for utility companies, Federal agencies, and States based on the study results. SEC. 4. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO RURAL AND SMALL MUNICIPALITIES AND TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS. Section 104(b) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to make grants to nonprofit organizations for providing technical assistance to rural and small municipalities and tribal governments in planning, development, and financing of eligible projects. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to provide grants to nonprofit organizations for technical assistance in planning, development, and financing of eligible projects, including decentralized wastewater treatment systems. The purpose is to protect water quality, ensure compliance with the Act, and disseminate information to rural and small municipalities, tribal governments, and municipalities meeting affordability criteria. SEC. 5 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to establish a grant program for repairing, replacing, or upgrading residential onsite sewage disposal systems. SEC. 6 addresses state water pollution control revolving funds. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include new requirements for state financial assistance projects. This includes restrictions on funding for projects benefiting new communities and the application of section 513 requirements to treatment works funded by state water pollution control revolving funds. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to allow assistance for purchasing privately owned treatment works and canceling contracts for publicly owned treatment works. Additionally, the limit of additional subsidization by the state is increased to 50 percent. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to increase the state's limit on additional subsidization to 50 percent of the total capitalization grants received for a fiscal year. SEC. 7. USE OF STATE REVOLVING LOAN FUNDS UNDER THE SAFE DRINKING WATER ACT. Section 1452 of the Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to allow the use of funds for purchasing privately owned community water systems or for canceling contracts related to the operation or management of a community water system. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to allow assistance for public water systems serving fewer than 10,000 persons not owned, operated, or managed by any entity with another public water system. Additionally, the percentage of assistance in subsection (d)(2) is increased to 50 percent, and subsection (g)(3) includes guidance for affordable, equitable, transparent, and reliable water and sewer service. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to provide assistance for public water systems serving fewer than 10,000 persons not owned by another public water system. Assistance percentage is increased to 50 percent, with guidance for affordable, equitable, transparent, and reliable water and sewer service provision. Assistance is also provided for replacing lead service lines with lead-free lines on private properties. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to establish grant programs for school drinking water improvement and tribal drinking water. Grants will be provided for installing, repairing, or replacing infrastructure for drinking water facilities and testing water quality at schools. Additionally, assistance is increased for public water systems serving fewer than 10,000 people and for replacing lead service lines with lead-free lines on private properties.
